awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Elucidating Chemical Mechanisms of DNA Repair Using Transition State Analogs
awd_abstract_narration:
The information held within the DNA blueprint for life can be eroded by damage to DNA bases due to cellular metabolism and environmental exposures.   Modified DNA bases lead to changes in the DNA sequence called mutations. These mutations can negatively impact cellular processes but they can be corrected by the action of DNA repair enzymes.  With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Sheila David at the University of California Davis and Dr. Martin Horvath at the University of Utah to uncover molecular details of how damaged DNA bases are detected and repaired.   The research makes uses of synthetic DNA chemistry and X-ray crystallography to trap and visualize steps in the DNA repair process that are otherwise too fleeting to study and to generate a detailed molecular picture of the DNA repair process.  Graduate and undergraduate students learn how to combine different chemistry and biology approaches to reveal and understand key features of fundamental life processes. This project is also integrated into a unique "Course-Based Research Experience" (CURE) laboratory course taught at both the University of California Davis and the University of Utah.  Undergraduates emerge from the course with improved critical thinking skills and a better conceptual knowledge of how information crucial for living organisms is encoded in their DNA and maintained by DNA repair enzymes.
 
This research project delineates chemical mechanisms of base excision repair (BER) glycosylases to illuminate how these enzymes efficiently find rare modified DNA bases. Modified nucleotides that mimic transition states are prepared through synthetic chemistry. Structural studies of several BER glycosylases bound to DNA containing these transition state mimics provide insight into the catalysis of base excision. Indeed, surprising features uncovered with three BER glycosylases, namely MutY, AlkD and MBD4, raise new questions on these and related glycosylases and prompt new innovative structural and functional studies that will be pursued by the David and Horvath research groups.  Students working on this project receive interdisciplinary training spanning synthetic nucleic acid chemistry, nucleic acid enzymology, and DNA-protein crystallography. Fostering environments in which women and minority students thrive is a core goal of the work supported by this award. This project has a positive broader educational impact because it is tied to two undergraduate laboratory courses that introduce incoming and advanced undergraduate students to modern research techniques and approaches used in chemical biology with a focus on DNA damage and repair.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
DNA is the blueprint for life.  Modifications of DNA, considered DNA damage, caused by cellular metabolism or by environmental hazards can lead to mutations, cell death, or changes in the blueprint over the course of evolution. The preservation of DNA relies on the action of DNA repair enzymes.  Despite years of work that have uncovered DNA repair enzymes and the types of damage they act upon, mysteries remain as to how these amazing enzymes work at the molecular level.  Indeed, the processes by which these enzymes rapidly detect rare and subtle damaged DNA bases within the context of a large excess of normal DNA is not only truly remarkable but also absolutely essential for life.  In this project, synthetic DNA chemistry, X-ray crystallography and single molecule assays were used to visualize individual steps in the DNA repair process.  For example, structural studies revealed a small loop within the DNA repair enzyme MutY that is required to detect an oxidized form of guanine (called OG) over normal guanine.  These structural inferences were directly visualized using assays that allowed for watching of fluorescent-labeled MutY moving along DNA tightropes containing damaged DNA!  Using a combination of synthetic chemistry and enzyme engineering, we also were able to capture structural snapshots of the entire repair process from initial engagement of the damaged base pair by MutY to formation of the final product.  Similar approaches were leveraged to reveal structures of MutY homologs found in extreme environments, and related DNA repair enzymes.  These illustrate how the chemical mechanisms are conserved in evolution but utilizing different structural strategies related to roles in biology and the environment.  We also created new synthetic tools that are being used by other laboratories to trap and visual DNA repair enzymes in action.  This work illustrates how these remarkable enzymes efficiently recognize and excise only damaged bases without compromising the rest of the genome.  This work has revealed common themes and unique features in the chemistry underlying DNA repair.  This fundamental insight impacts chemistry of life processes related to a broad array of disciplines including genomics, environmental sciences, evolution and biotechnology.

 

Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project have acquired interdisciplinary training spanning synthetic nucleic acid chemistry, nucleic acid enzymology, and DNA-protein crystallography.  They have learned important lessons in combining different approaches to unlock key features of fundamental life processes.  The discoveries and results produced by this project also form the cornerstone of two distinct and unique DNA damage and repair laboratory classes for undergraduates taught at UC Davis and the University of Utah. Undergraduates in these courses emerge with skills in critical thinking and conceptual knowledge related to how the information of life is encoded in DNA and maintained by DNA repair enzymes. Both PIs are committed to activities that broaden participation in science, including activities that foster favorable environments for women and minority undergraduate and graduate students.  The rigorous scientific training provided for students working directly on the research project in the laboratory, and the students involved in the associated courses will provide the basis for them to make contributions to society in many ways, such as in careers in industry, academia, science policy and law.
